page.title: 01VENTNOR AND BONCHURCH.
page.content: This block covers the extreme South Eastern corner of the Isle of Wight. It contains the town centre of Ventnor and the village of Bonchurch, which was mentioned in the Domesday Book as Bonacerce. Ventnor consisted of a number of small cottages and an inn until the early nineteenth century when the publication of a medical treatise suggested the climate was good for pulmonary disorders. Speculators moved in and most of the buildings in this part of Ventnor date from around 1860. Ventnor is built on a series of terraces and is dominated by St. Boniface Down which rises to nearly 800 feet and is the highest point of the Island. Ventnor is now a popular holiday resort but Bonchurch remains unspoilt. The Landslip lies to the N.E. of Bonchurch.
